Award.AwardTitle: Technique Development for Caffeinated Beverage Identification

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The great power archaeology has is the ability to teach about our collective past and provide a perspective on people today. A key part of that collective past, as well as the present, is beliefs and associated belief practices. Because the material remains of beliefs are often transitory and open to interpretation, this realm of human behavior is often under-studied by those who explore the deep past. This project intends to refine the methods used to identify the use of, and ultimately explore the ancient ritual practices surrounding, caffeinated beverages in the Americas. Before the coming of Europeans to the New World, caffeinated beverages were made either using a species of holly (yaupon or dahoon holly) in North America, or chocolate in Central America. Historical and archaeological information show that beverages made from these plants were consumed in ritual and specialized contexts, so understanding how and when they were used will make it possible to explore the ritual practices surrounding those uses. This will be done while helping to train the next generation of archaeologists and supporting indigenous businesses in Belize and the US.

The search for the remains of foods and other concoctions in ancient containers is most often done by attempting to detect the presence of diagnostic compounds that had been absorbed into the matrix of the container. Most absorbed residue studies employ some version of mass spectrometry to detect and measure the concentration of various compounds present in residue samples collected from ancient containers. The problem with absorbed residue studies of caffeinated beverages in the Americas is that the compounds and concentrations thought to distinguish chocolate from yaupon holly do not, in fact, differentiate residues produced by the two plants. This project will search for chemical compounds that definitively distinguish the two plants sources and the beverages made from them. This will be done by analyzing samples derived from the plant sources, the beverages made using traditional methods, and fragments of low-fired ceramic vessels spiked with those beverages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Before the coming of Europeans Indigenous people of North and Central American consumed caffeinated drinks, usually as part of rituals or elite privilege. In Central America, those drinks were made from cacao, or chocolate, while in eastern North America, where cacao does not grow, they were made from yaupon holly. For decades archaeologists have been able to find evidence of cacao consumption in pre-Columbian Central American contexts using the chemical characterization of residues absorbed into containers. More recently, scholars have attempted to do the same with yaupon holly residues. Traditionally, the two kinds of drinks were distinguished by the presence of a single compound—theophylline—thought to be found only in cacao. In analyzing samples of yaupon holly, our team found that it too contains theophylline, which means the usual methods used to detect the two kinds of drinks cannot tell them apart.

Although cacao does not grow in North America, researchers have found evidence that it was consumed in Chaco Canyon, a very large Ancestral Pueblo community in New Mexico, and even more recently it has been argued that cacao was also consumed at the same time by people in the Mississippi and Ohio River Valleys. This suggests that cacao was brought to these places from central and southern Mexico and implies standing connections between people like the ancient Maya and Aztecs and the ancestors of today’s Native Americans. While there is other evidence of those connections with Ancestral Pueblo people, no evidence of connections between the inhabitants eastern North American and Central America have been found. Eastern North American is where yaupon holly grows naturally, making it possible that the residues detected actually indicate drinks made from it rather than cacao. That possibility needs to be evaluated, especially since traditional absorbed residue methods cannot distinguish cacao drinks from yaupon holly drinks. Our study attempts to find a compound that can be used to tell the two sources of caffeine apart in absorbed residues. Only then will it be possible to understand if Indigenous people of eastern North America had access to cacao.

Our project attempts to identify distinguishing compounds by making drinks from cacao and yaupon holly, dosing ceramic containers with those drinks, collecting absorbed residue samples from them, and analyzing those samples using mass spectrometry. Because of the pandemic and equipment problems our project remains incomplete. Thus far, cacao and yaupon holly beverages were made using traditional techniques and allowed to rest in ceramic containers created in Belize and the southeastern US using traditional pottery techniques. Samples of the beverages were collected for chemical characterization, as were samples of the resides from the ceramic containers. Four different sampling techniques were employed in collecting samples from those containers. Mass spectrometry will be used to identify chemical compounds that can distinguish the resides created by the cacao and yaupon holly drinks. Additionally, the four different sampling techniques will be evaluated to see which are the best for collecting caffeinated drink absorbed residues. We expect to complete the analyses of our samples by the end of 2021.

Our intent is to identify a robust set of methods that can be used to distinguish sources of caffeinated drinks used in pre-Columbian times in the Americas. The project so far has trained graduate students in the methods of collecting absorbed residue samples and also given chemistry graduate students the chance to apply their mass spectrometry knowledge to our practical problem. We hope that the studies we can conduct once our new methods are established will make it possible to more fully explore the potential for connections between eastern North American and Central America. We also hope future studies may help descendant communities in the Americas connect to their past in meaningful ways.
